metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: Emojis are characters from the UTF-8 character set: 😄 😍 💗
content.html: Emojis are characters from the UTF-8 character set: 😄 😍 💗

content.text: Emojis look like images, or icons, but they are not.
content.html: Emojis look like images, or icons, but they are not.

content.text: They are letters (characters) from the UTF-8 (Unicode) character set.
content.html: They are letters (characters) from the UTF-8 (Unicode) character set.

content.text: UTF-8 covers almost all of the characters and symbols in the world.
content.html: UTF-8 covers almost all of the characters and symbols in the world.

content.text: To display an HTML page correctly, a web browser must know the character set used in the page.
content.html: To display an HTML page correctly, a web browser must know the character set used in the page.

content.text: This is specified in the <meta> tag:

content.code_html: <meta charset="UTF-8">

content.text: If not specified, UTF-8 is the default character set in HTML.
content.html: If not specified, UTF-8 is the default character set in HTML.

content.text: Many UTF-8 characters cannot be typed on a keyboard, but they can always be displayed using numbers (called entity numbers):
content.html: Many UTF-8 characters cannot be typed on a keyboard, but they can always be displayed using numbers (called entity numbers):

content.code:
I will display A B C

I will display A B C
content.code_html:
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<meta charset="UTF-8">
<body>

<p>I will display A B C</p>
<p>I will display A B C</p>

</body>
</html>

content.text: The <meta charset="UTF-8"> element defines the character set.
content.html: The <meta charset="UTF-8"> element defines the character set.

content.text: The characters A, B, and C, are displayed by the numbers 65, 66, and 67.
content.html: The characters A, B, and C, are displayed by the numbers 65, 66, and 67.

content.text: To let the browser understand that you are displaying a character, you must start the entity number with &# and end it with ; (semicolon).
content.html: To let the browser understand that you are displaying a character, you must start the entity number with &# and end it with ; (semicolon).

content.text: Emojis are also characters from the UTF-8 alphabet:
content.html: Emojis are also characters from the UTF-8 alphabet:

content.code_html:
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<meta charset="UTF-8">
<body>

<h1>My First Emoji</h1>

<p>😀</p>

</body>
</html>

content.text: Since Emojis are characters, they can be copied, displayed, and sized just like any other character in HTML.
content.html: Since Emojis are characters, they can be copied, displayed, and sized just like any other character in HTML.

content.code_html:
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<meta charset="UTF-8">
<body>

<h1>Sized Emojis</h1>

<p style="font-size:48px">
😀 😄 😍 💗
</p>

</body>
</html>
